an6.38:4.1: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha,
an6.38:4.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
an6.38:4.5: “Master Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:
an6.38:4.6: One does not act of one’s own volition, nor does one act of another’s volition.”
an6.38:4.7: “Well, brahmin, I’ve never seen or heard of anyone holding such a doctrine or view.
an6.38:4.8: How on earth can someone who comes and goes on his own say that
an6.38:4.9: one does not act of one’s own volition, nor does one act of another’s volition?
an6.38:5.1: What do you think, brahmin, is there an element of initiative?”
an6.38:5.3: “Since this is so, do we find sentient beings who initiate activity?”
an6.38:5.5: “Since there is an element of initiative, and sentient beings who initiate activity are found, sentient beings act of their own volition or that of another.
an6.38:6.1: What do you think, brahmin, is there an element of persistence …
an6.38:6.7: “Since this is so, do we find sentient beings who have energy?”
an6.38:6.9: “Since there is an element of force, and sentient beings who have energy are found, sentient beings act of their own volition or that of another.
an6.38:7.1: Well, brahmin, I’ve never seen or heard of anyone holding such a doctrine or view.
an6.38:7.2: How on earth can someone who comes and goes on his own say that
an6.38:7.3: one does not act of one’s own volition, nor does one act of another’s volition?”
an6.38:8.2: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
